author: Amber Thomas

intro.value: This is my Netflix account. We’ve been spending a lot of time together lately, but one of its quirks has started to get under my skin. If I leave the app idle on my TV, a screensaver starts advertising its titles paired with three descriptive words. It looks something like the illustration below. After watching it for a while, I noticed one, single, maddening word used more than the rest.

postTV.value: Irreverent. Irreverent. Irreverent. C’mon Netflix, this is the word that dominates the descriptions of your shows? At least on my account, it was the most common tag appearing alongside 26% of advertised titles.

preDef: In case (like me), you need a little refresher on the definition of irreverent, don’t feel bad. It’s the only one of the most common tags that’s an actual SAT word. Here’s the definition:
def: Irreverent: showing a lack of respect for people or things that are generally taken seriously

postComplaint.value: Interestingly enough, this implies that by definition it shouldn’t be a common descriptor for media. Afterall, if everything is poking fun at things generally taken seriously, is anything taking them seriously? If everything is irreverent, is anything? Either way, I was starting to see the word irreverent in my dreams.

Now, I know what you’re going to say. Netflix’s algorithms are probably surfacing things that it thinks I would like based on my own viewing preferences. It’s certainly possible that I’ve been causing my own irreverent doom.

So, I created a brand new profile with no viewing preferences, which according to Netflix, should display “a diverse and popular set of titles”. Even with this new account, irreverent was the second most common tag used.
